div1.head: INDEX
div1.p: References are to Book and Section; all dates, given in parentheses (...), are B.C.

p.#text: 1. adherents of the New Academy (); their right to teach ethics, .
1. the Older, a school of philosophy founded by Plato and so called from its home; their doctrine of ideas, , .
the pre-existence and immortality of the soul; monotheism; the goodness of God; striving after His perfection. .
the New, a modification of the Old, sceptical, anti-dogmatic, eclectic, .
a tragic poet (born ). His tragedies were mostly imitations from the Greek. Cicero knew him personally; quotes from him, , , .
(tribune, ); interpreter, when Carneades, Diogenes, and Critolaus came to Rome; author of History of Rome, .

div2.head: Admiration
p: fg.

p.#text: descendants of Aeacus (), the father of Peleus and Telamon and grandfather of Achilles and Ajax, .

div2.head: Aeacus

p.#text: son of Zeus (Jupiter) and king of Aegina (); renowned for his justice and piety, .

p: after his death he became with Minos and Rhadamanthus judge in Hades.

p.#text: an island in the Saronic Gulf, a dangerous rival to Athens, directly in front of Piraeus and only twelve miles away, .
a warlike mountain tribe on the upper Anio, warring against Rome (till ), .
an intimate friend of Cicero, Rome's greatest tragic actor, .
the province in which Carthage was,  (Thapsus);  (Carthage).

div2.head: Agamemnon

p.#text: leader of the war against Troy; when detained at Aulis he sacrificed his daughter Iphigenia to save the expedition, .

p: For this he was slain on his return from Troy by his wife Clytaemnestra.

p.#text: king of Sparta (); waged war in Asia (), victor at Coronea, saviour of Sparta after Mantinea (); .

king of Sparta (); attempted to re-establish the
institutions of Lycurgus and reform property abuses; put to death through organized wealth .
a menace to the stability of the government, .

p.quote: the most beautiful city of mortals,
p.#text: a city on the south coast of Sicily, once  ruled by Phalaris (), .
son of Telamon; could brook no wrong, went mad, and committed suicide when the arms of Achilles were awarded to Odysseus, .
Subject of a tragedy by Ennius, .
an Epicurean; praetor in Sardinia (); prosecuted for extortion, .
the Great (), son of Philip of Macedon, , .
greater than his father in achievement, inferior in courtliness, .
conquered Greece (), subdued Asia (), Egypt (), invaded India (), founded Alexandria and other cities, and died of a drunken debauch (I, ).
tyrant of Pherae (); brother, son-in-law, and successor of Jason (), defeated and slew Pelopidas of Thebes at Cynoscephalae (); murdered by his wife and her three brothers, , .
the metropolis of Egypt at the mouth of the Nile; founded by Alexander (); centre of wealth (II, ); grain market, .
the mountains between Italy and further Gaul, .
the Sabine river, tributary to the Tiber; the battle on (), which gave Rome supremacy over all Latium, .

of Cyrene (4th century), a successor of Aristippus; his school a cross between the Epicurean and the Cyrenaic: he denied that pleasure was merely absence of pain; he held that every act had its own distinct purpose and that the virtues are good in themselves; his teachings were not permanent, .
one of Alexander's generals, governor of Asia (), king of Asia (); father of Demetrius Poliorcetes and Philip, .
mother of Amphion and Zethus, by whom she was saved from the persecutions of her former husband Lycus and his wife Dirce; her vengeance on Dirce drove her mad; subject of a tragedy of Pacuvius, .
vice-regent of Macedon (); father of Cassander, .
Antipater, of Tarsus (2nd century), pupil and successor of Diogenes of Babylonia; teacher of Panaetius; his ethical teachings, , .
of Tyre (1st century), friend of Cato the younger; a Stoic, .

div2.head: Marcus Antonius
p: father of Cicero's colleague and grandfather of the triumvir.

p.#text: of Cos (4th century), the greatest painter of his age; court painter to Alexander the Great; is masterpiece was a Venus rising from the sea; another Venus left unfinished, .
god of the light of day; giver of oracles at Pytho, .
famous jurist; Cicero's colleague in the praetorship; author of formulae on criminal fraud, .
consul () with Marius; victorious in the Servile War in Sicily; prosecuted () but acquitted, .

div2.head: Aratus

p.#text:
of Sicyon, soldier and statesman (), removed the tyrant Nicoles () and averted



financial ruin, , .

p: leader of the Achaean League; poisoned by order of Philip of Macedon.

div2.head: Areopagites
div2.p: members of the Council of Areopagus.

p.#text: a spur of the Acropolis, seat of the highest court of Athens; the court itself, with powers of senate and supreme court, reorganized and enlarged in function by Solon, .
a group of islands off the coast of Asia Minor, near Lesbos, scene of the victory of the Athenian fleet (), .
fought at Marathon (), Salamis (), and commanded the Athenians at Plataea (); exiled () because his policies clashed with those of Themistocles.
of Cyrene (flourished ), founder of the Cyrenaic school, .

disciple of Socrates, but taught that the chief end of man was to get enjoyment from everything (hedonism), to subject all things and circumstances to himself for pleasure; but pleasure must be the slave not the master; good and bad identical with pleasure and pain; .
of Chios (3rd century), a Stoic philosopher, pupil of Zeno; he taught indifference to externals, nothing good but virtue, nothing evil but vice; his theories rejected, .

(), disciple of Plato and teacher of Alexander the Great; founder of the Peripatetic school; greatest of philosophers, master of all knowledgephysics, metaphysics, natural philosophy, ethics, politics, poetics, sociology, logic, rhetoric, etc.; ; .
might have been a great orator, .
the people of Arpinum owners of public lands, .
a town in Latium, birth place of Cicero and Gaius Marius, .
left their homes to fight at Salamis, .
the intellectual and artistic centre of the world; led Greece in the Persian wars (); humbled by Sparta (); the university city of the Roman world, ; , .
son of Pelops and father of Agamemnon and Menelaus, murderer of his half-brother Chrysippus and of his brother Thyestes's children; murdered by his nephew Aegisthus; a fruitful theme for tragedy, ; .
belonging to Attica, the province in which Athens is situated; Attic comedy, the comedy of Aristophanes, Eupolis, Menander, etc., .
due to delusion as to expediency, .
the district around Babylon at the head of the Persian Gulf, .

king of Illyria, conquered a large part of Macedonia from Perdiccas, the brother and predecessor of Philip; defeated and slain by Philip (); called a  because his career did not tend to promote civilization, .
Minucius, otherwise unknown; perhaps Sulla's lieutenant, .

Junius, led the



Romans to expel the Tarquins; helped by Collatinus, who shared with him the first consulship (), .
Junius, an eminent jurist, one of the three founders of the civil law; father of  .
orator and vigorous prosecutor, son of the preceding, .
Julius, son of Lucius Caesar Strabo Vopiscus, candidate for the consulship (), slain by Marius (); poet and orator, , .
Julius (), consul (), in Gaul (), conquered Pompey at Pharsalus (), dictator (), assassinated (); orator, statesman, scholar, soldier; despot, .
a conspirator with Catiline, his love of wrong, .
succeeded Lysander as admiral of the Spartan fleet, .
defeated Conon, took Lesbos, lost the battle and his life at Arginusae (), .
a Greek philosopher, probably a disciple of Epicurus, taught that the supreme good was a union between moral rectitude and pleasure, .
the nymph of Ogygia, who kept Odysseus (Ulysses) with her seven years, .
(Martius), the open plain next to the Tiber outside the north wall of Rome; playground and drillground, .
a town on the Aufidus in Apulia, scene of Hannibal's overwhelming defeat of the Romans (), ; , .
the Capitoline Hill, between the forum and the Tiber, the citadel of Rome, with the temple of Jupiter and Good Faith, .
once a mighty city, on the north central coast of Africa, , .
the most formidable commercial and military rival of Rome; conquered by Rome in the First Punic War (), .
son of Antipater, disinherited by his father, gained the throne of Macedonia () by wars and murders (), .

div2.head: Marcus Cato

p.#text: Porcius, the Censor (or Major, the Elder, I, ) (), author, ; .
soldier, served in Second Punic War (); statesman, responsible for the destruction of Carthage (), ;  .
consul (); censor (); stalwart champion of the simple life and stern morals, .

p: bitterly opposed luxury and Greek culture; yielded in old age.

p.#text: Porcius, son of the preceding; jurist; served under Paulus in Macedon (), ; [under Marcus Popilius Laenas in Liguria (), ].
Porcius, grandson of the Censor and father of Cato Uticensis, .

(), son of the preceding and great-grandson of the Cen-



sor; a Stoic philosopher; orator; soldier, .
stern and unyielding as his great-grandfather, ; .
Lutatius, half-brother of Julius Caesar Strabo, .
author; soldier; consul with Marius () in the war against the Cimbri (); gentleman, .
committed suicide to escape the proscriptions of Marius ().
Lutatius, son of the preceding, defeated Lepidus at the Milvian bridge; statesman, .
a little town in the mountains of Samnium; near it are the Caudine Forks, the scene of the disastrous battle (); ; (II, ).
a powerful people of central Spain, opposed Rome in Second Punic War, were reduced in the Numantian War (), submitted on the death of Sertorius (), .

p.quote: Had there been no Chrysippus, there had been no Stoa,
p.#text: of Soli (), studied Stoic philosophy at Athens under Cleanthes, whom he succeeded; voluminous writer.  .

Tullius, the orator (), born at Arpinum, educated at Rome under Archias, the Scaevolas, and the teachers of philosophy ( Introduction), at Athens, in Asia, and at Rhodes; his training was all for service, .
as consul () he crushed the conspiracy of Catiline, .
his enforced retirement from his profession, .
attitude on the downfall of the republic, .
and Sextus Pompey; a student of Peripatetic philosophy under Cratippus in Athens (), .
admonished to read also his father's works, ; .
served under Brutus (); consul with Octavian ().
a Celtic people, migrating in a vast horde toward Italy, were cut to pieces by Marius and Catulus in the Raudian Plains near Verona (), .
of Athens, son of the great Miltiades; victorious admiral; statesman; genial and generous, .
nymph of Aeaea, a sorceress; she kept Odysseus (Ulysses) in her halls a year, .

div2.head: Civic
p: fg.

p.#text: son of Pausanias, king of Sparta, fell at Leuctra (), .

Cicero's inveterate enemy, one of the most turbulent and corrupt characters of Rome, guilty of mutiny in the army, bribery in the courts, profligacy in his public and private life.; secured Cicero's banishment; hired gladiators to force his own election to the praetorship, but was killed in a broil with Milo's rival gang of ruffians, .
a Roman girl sent as a hostage to Porsena; she made her escape by swimming the Tiber, was sent back, but restored by the king with rewards for her courage, .

daughter of Tyndareus, wife of Agamemnon,



paramour of Aegisthus, with whom she murdered her husband on his return from Troy; she was in turn slain by her son Orestes. Subject of a tragedy by Accius, .
the hero who with two others kept the bridge against Porsena and Tarquin, .
Tarquinius, husband of Lucretia, associate of Brutus in driving out the Tarquins and his colleague in the first consulship (), .
famous Athenian admiral, defeated by Lysander at Aegospotami (), victorious over Pisander of Sparta at Cnidus (), restored the long walls, .
a subdivision of the virtue of Temperance, , .

div2.head: Co-operation
p: fg.

p.#text: a famous city at the Isthmus of Corinth; wealthy; next to Athens, richest in treasures of art; head of the Achaean League; sacked and utterly destroyed by the Romans under Mummius (), ; ; .
chief city of the island of Cos, one of the Sporades; famed for its silks; the birthplace of Apelles, painter of the Coan Venus, .
Aurelius, distinguished orator; one of the speakers in Cicero's  and  consul (); .
at  () he won renown by his prosecution of Carbo, the one-time friend of the Gracchi, , .
as consul (), he secured the expulsion from Rome of all who were not citizens, .
this was a cause of the Social War. He was the greatest orator of Rome before Cicero, fluent, graceful, witty, , .
the triumvir; his wealth and ambition, .
sided with Sulla against Marius and grew enormously rich by the proscriptions; his avarice did not shrink from any meanness or even crime, ; .
He defeated Spartacus (); slain in Parthia ().
father of the triumvir, consul (); ended his own life to escape the proscriptions of Marius (); Cicero bought his house.
of Mitylene, an eminent Peripatetic, came to Athens (about ) to lecture; foremost of contemporary philosophers and teacher of young Cicero, , ; ; , , , .

a school of philosophy so called from the Athenian gymnasium, Cynosarges, where they met, later adapted to their snarling manner and dirty habits; its leaders were Antisthenes of Athens, a disciple of Socrates, and Diogenes of Sinope; they taught the virtue of poverty and want, indifference to all convention and decency; Cicero's contempt for them and their so-called philosophy, , .
the philosophic sect founded by Aristippus (), .

the Great, founder of the



Persian Empire; wonderfully gifted in winning the co-operation of men and nations, .
a Pythagorean and friend of Phintias, .
the former, consul with Manlius Torquatus (), devoted himself to death in the battle on the Veseris. The son did the same at the battle of Sentinum () and brought the Samnite wars to an end.

div2.head: Demetrius of Phalerum

p.#text: the only Greek who was both orator and philosopher, .

p: he inspired the founding of the Alexandrine library.

p.#text: son of Antigonus and king of Macedon (). His life was occupied with continuous warfare against enemies in Egypt, Asia, Greece, Macedonia, Epirus.

div2.head: Demosthenes

p.#text: the greatest orator of Athens (); pupil of Isaeus and of Plato, .
might have been a great philosopher, .
he prosecuted his defaulting guardian with success, .

p: then turned to public speaking and statecraft as a profession.

p.#text: goddess of the light of the night, identified with Artemis, .

div2.head: Dicaearchus

p.#text: of Messana (4th century), a Peripatetic philosopher, geographer, and historian, .

p: pupil of Aristotle and friend of Theophrastus.

p.#text: a Greek philosopher, always named with Calliphon (), .

of Babylonia, pupil and successor of Chrysippus; best known for his part in the famous embassy with Carneades and Critolaus from Athens to Rome (), where, on motion of Cato, they were not permitted to remain; his ethics rather loose, , .
a kinsman of the elder Dionysius and tyrant of Syracuse (); a devoted disciple of Plato at Syracuse and Athens, .
the elder (), tyrant of Syracuse (), a typically cruel tyrant, suspicious and fearful, ;  (?); devoted to art and literature, himself a poet crowned with a prize at Athens.

the younger, son of the preceding and tyrant of Syracuse (367356, ); devoted to literature; Plato, Aristippus, Archytas, and others were brought to his court. Whether the Damon and Phintias story is to be connected with him or his father is uncertain,  (?).
Livius, son of Gaius Gracchus's colleague in the tribuneship; an eloquent orator, .
as tribune () he attempted to renew the social and agrarian legislation of Gracchus and was assassinated.
the most important subject in philosophy, .
to those who have wronged us, .
change of duty in change of circumstance, , ; ;  and  duty, ; .

div2.head: Quintus Ennius

p.#text: (), a Greek by birth, the father of Roman poetry, wrote an epic (the Annals), .

p: comedies and satires.

p.#text: one of the greatest men of Greece, a student of Pythagorean philosophy, .
the greatest general of Thebes, victorious at Leuctra (), .
humbled Sparta and made Thebes the leading city of Greece; fell at Mantinea ().

(), founded at Athens the school that bears his name; author of 300 books, natural and ethical philosophy; held happiness to be the highest good; Cicero confuses his teaching here with that of Aristippus and the Cyrenaics; with the latter, happiness consists in individual pleasures; with Epicurus, it is permanent calm of soul and freedom from pain, with pure and lasting pleasuresthe pleasures that come from a life of righteousness, , .
the gods existed but had nothing to do with human life, .
adopted the atomic theory. His own life was temperate even to abstinence; his followers went to excess. A very popular school, .
the sons of the Seven against Thebes; under Alcmaeon, Diomedes, etc., they conquered and destroyed the city. Subject of a tragedy of Accius, .
of Carthage, pupil of Zeno the Stoic, held that knowledge is the only good, while everything else is neither good nor evil; his ethical theories rejected, .
son of Oedipus, drove out his brother Polynices, in order to reign alone, and brought on the war of the Seven against Thebes; the brothers fell by each other's hands, .
(), tragic poet of Athens; disciple of Anaxagoras and friend of Socrates; wrote 75 to 90 plays; 17 are extant; Cicero quotes from the  .
hero of old Rome, famed for integrity and moral dignity; called  , .
consul (); served against Pyrrhus (); ambassador to Pyrrhus to negotiate exchange of prisoners; Pyrrhus tried to gain his favour by appeals to his ambition, avarice, and fearsin vain, .
consul again (), he sent back to Pyrrhus the traitor, ; .
a rigorous censor (); lived and died in poverty.
dangerous to the one who employs it, .

the laws of the  a college of four priests who served as guardians of the public faith; they conducted the ceremonies attendant upon demands for redress, declarations of war, ratification of treaties, establishment of peace; ; .
Flavius, colleague of Marius in his second consulship (); orator and jurist, .

div2.head: Fraud
p: fg.

p.#text: an orator of no great ability, .
an inhabitant of Gaul, the land north of the Apennines, .
must not harm its object, : in proportion to one's means, ; .

Sempronius, brother of the younger Tiberius; a more radical reformer; tribune ( and ); fell () a martyr to his reforms for the restoration of the public lands and the reduction of the cost of living, , .
Sempronius, father of the elder Tiberius, .
in his own tribuneship he defended Scipio (); a great soldier, .
twice consul, triumphed twice; a just ruler in Spain; son-in-law of the elder, father-in-law of the younger Africanus, an ardent aristocrat; hence Cicero's praise, .

Sempronius, son of the foregoing; a persuasive orator; friend of the people and helper of the poor and oppressed; murdered for attempting as tribune () to reform agrarian abuses and build up a class of small farmers, , ; .
the land of liberty, letters, art, and civilization, ; , , .
belonging to or a native of Greece, , ; ; .
the shepherd who dethroned Candaules and became king of Lydia (), , .
the harbour-town and arsenal of Sparta, .
a successful Carthaginian general in the First Punic War, defeated by Regulus at Ecnomus; opposed Regulus in Africa, .
famous commander of the Carthaginian forces in Sicily (); in Spain (); father of Hannibal, .
(), one of the world's greatest generals, .
sacked Saguntum (), crossed the Alps and defeated the Romans on the Trebia and Ticinus (), at Trasimenus (), Cannae (), ; .
defeated at Zama (); maligned by the Romans as treacherous and cruel, .

div2.head: Harm
p: fg.

p.#text: of Rhodes, a Stoic, pupil of Panaetius, , .
the greatest of heroes, son of Zeus (Jupiter) and Alcmena, .
his choice of his path in life, .
performer of the twelve labours; benefactor of humanity, .
a tribe in the Sabine mountains, subdued by Rome (), .
of Halicarnassus (5th century), lived also at Athens and Thurii; the father of history; travelled widely and wrote the history of Persia and Greece, .
the Boeotian didactic poet (8th century); author of the Theogony, the Works and Days, etc., .
son of Theseus; his step-mother Phaedra fell in love with him; he rejected her advances but promised not to tell, .
she accused him falsely; his innocence proved, Phaedra hanged herself and Theseus suffered life-long remorse, ; .
the poet, author of Iliad and Odyssey, .

div2.head: Honesty
p: fg.

p.#text: suitable for a man of rank, .
(), Cicero's famous rival as orator and advocate; his close friend (after ), .
enormously wealthy; lavish in his aedileship (), .
the country between Macedonia and the Adriatic, .
daughter of Agamemnon and Clytaemnestra (); sacrificed at Aulis, .
(), one of the ten Attic orators, pupil of Gorgias and Socrates; a polished speaker; greater as a teacher than as an orator; might have been a great philosopher, .

div2.head: Italian War

p.#text: (), caused by Rome's injustice to the allies, provoked by the fear of prosecution on the part of the corrupt aristocrats, .

p: resulted in Rome's granting the contentions of the allies.

p.#text: the home of Odysseus (Ulysses), an island of the Ionian group west of Greece, probably the historical Leucas, .
an old Italian sungod; a covered passage (commonly called his temple) adjoining the forum accommodated the banking houses of Rome, .
tyrant of Pherae (), generalissimo of Thessaly (), an able soldier and diplomat, .
king of Numidia (), campaigned with Scipio against Numantia; war with Rome () protracted by his bribes as much as by his arms, .
the greatest of the gods of Italy, , ;  .
Fabius, grandson of Fabius Maximus, consul (); injustice of, .
citizens of the deme of Lacia, west of Athens, the home of Miltiades, .

div2.head: Gaius Laelius

p.#text: statesman; soldier under Scipio at Carthage, successful against Viriathus, .
a Stoic, pupil of Diogenes and Panaetius; a man of endless charm and wit, , .

p: a man of letters, centre of the literary group comprising also Scipio, Panaetius, Polybius, Terence, Lucilius.

p.#text: the people of Latium, the province in which Rome is situated, the first territory added to Rome, .
its decline with the end of the republic, ; .
as consul () he was largely instrumental in securing Cicero's recall from banishment.
a town of Boeotia, where the Spartans under Cleombrotus were disastrously defeated by Epaminondas and the Thebans (), ; .

div2.head: Lucius Lucullus

p.#text: Licinius (), surnamed Ponticus for his victories over Mithradates (); famed for his wealth and magnificence, .
for the splendour of his aedileship with his brother Marcus (), .
with him prosecuted Servilius to avenge their father whom he had accused of bribery and corruption, .

p: patron of letters, especially of the poet Archias.

div2.head: Marcus Lucullus

p.#text: Licinius, associated with his brother Lucius (), , .

p: soldier and orator.

p.#text: (9th century), the famous lawgiver of Sparta, author (?) of the Spartan constitution, .
the central country of western Asia Minor, .
the Spartan admiral who defeated the Athenians at Aegospotami (), received the capitulation of Athens (), established the Thirty Tyrants (), and gave Sparta her leadership, , .

the ephor (), a descendant of the admiral, a friend of King Agis (), sought to bring



about agrarian reforms based upon the constitution of Lycurgus; for this he was banished, .
of Tarentum, a Pythagorean; expelled from Italy, he came to Thebes and taught Epaminondas, .
until the time of Philip a small country north of Thessaly, .
tribune (), more probably tribune-elect, as tribunes could not leave the city, .
a kinsman of Caesar; though defeated once, .
Hostilius; in his consulship () he was defeated by the Numantines; his delivery to the enemy, .
named dictator to mark the year (), he used his office to engage in a war; that he transgressed but a  was due to the intervention of the tribunes, .
his son, a famous hero of Roman story; as consul at the time of the battle on the Veseris he executed his own son for disobeying orders, though the disobedience won the  .
a plain about twenty miles north of Athens where () Miltiades and his ten thousand defeated the hosts of Darius, .
Claudius, campaigned against Hannibal in Italy, took Syracuse (), five times consul, a brave but cruel soldier, over-praised by the Romans, .

div2.head: Gaius Marius

p.#text: (), seven times consul; gained his first consulship dishonourably, , .
conquered Jugurtha (); saved Rome from the invading Cimbri () and Teutons (); a military genius, .

p: cruel and selfish, he flooded the streets of Rome with her best blood in the civil war with Sulla.

p.#text: the son (or grandson) of Marcus Gratidius whose sister married Cicero's grandfather; adopted by a kinsman of the great Marius; hence his name; twice praetor; murdered by Catiline during Sulla's proscriptions, .
his unbounded popularity in his first praetorship (), .
(Massilia), a Greek city on the southern coast of Gaul, independent of the province; it sided with Pompey; Caesar captured the city after a protracted siege and exacted cruel vengeance, .
consul four times; in his second dictatorship () he won his surname by harassing Hannibal, watching his plans and working on the defensive, , .
the people of Media, a great kingdom in central Asia Minor added to Persia by Cyrus, .
a son of Media and Aegeus; wandering in search of his mother he came to Colchis, where Medea saved his life; the subject of a tragedy of Pacuvius, .
mother of Boeotus and Aeolus by Posidon (Neptune); blinded and imprisoned by her father, she was at last rescued by her sons and her sight was restored by Posidon; subject of a tragedy of Ennius, .

Quintus Caecilius Metellus



Macedonicus, won his surname by his victories over Andriscus (); a political rival and yet a good friend of the younger Scipio, .
nephew of the preceding, statesman and soldier; as consul (), carried on the war with Jugurtha with distinguished success, .
of Lampsacus (), the most distinguished of the disciples of Epicurus; his Epicureanism was of the grossly sensual sort; his conception of happiness misunderstood by Cicero, .

div2.head: Titus Milo

p.#text: Annius, an unscrupulous and turbulent fellow; as tribune () he did much for Cicero's recall and made a sworn enemy of Clodius (); hired gladiators to force his own election, .

p: defended without success by Cicero for killing Clodius.

p.#text: son of Zeus (Jupiter) and king of Crete; because of his upright life he was made judge with Aeacus () in Hades, .
as consul () broke up the Achaean League, razed Corinth to the ground, ; .
carried to Italy untold treasures of wealth and art, .
the beautiful Greek city of Campania, .
a city in Campania, loyal to Rome, .
the capital of Celtiberia, razed to the ground after a long siege by the younger Scipio, , .
as praetor commanded the fleet against Perseus () and gained a triumph; consul (), .
tribune (); had the corn law of Gaius Gracchus repealed and secured the passage of a new and more conservative one, .
that of Arietophanes, Cratinus, Eupolis, etc., the comedy of personal abuse, .

div2.head: Palamedes
p: treacherously done to death in revenge.

p.#text: the hill above the forum on the south; east of the Capitol, .
of Rhodes ( ), Stoic philosopher, disciple of Diogenes and Antipater () at Athens, close friend of Laelius () and Scipio, ; .
wrote a book on moral duty, .
how it would have been met, .

defends lawyers'



efforts in a bad case, .
as tribune (), revived the law of Pennus (), .
right to do wrong for one's country, .
Aemilius, consul (), defeated and slain at Cannae, .
son of the preceding; in his second consulship he conquered Perseus of Macedon at Pydna () and enriched Rome with spoils, .
the father of the younger Africanus, , .
king of Sparta, commander-in-chief of the forces of Greece at Plataea () to the glory of Sparta, .
the death-struggle of Athens with Sparta (), .
the lower peninsula of Greece, in which Sparta was the chief city, .
son of Tantalus and king of Mycenae, father of Atreus and Thyestes, .
Junius; as tribune () he secured a law expelling all foreigners from Rome, .
philosopher, friend of Anaxagoras and Socrates; orator of mighty power, serious and deep, .
his administration made Athens unequalled in the splendour of her public buildings, .
students of exact science; lack of poetry and eloquence of Plato but not very different from the New Academy, ; .
the last king of Macedon, conquered by Paulus (), .
the people of Persia, the great empire of western Asia; under Darius they invaded Greece and were beaten back at Marathon (), .
under Xerxes were overwhelmingly defeated at Salamis (), ; , .
daughter of Minos, wife of Theseus and stepmother of Hippolytus (), .

div2.head: Phalaris

p.#text: tyrant of Agrigentum (6th century), type of inhuman cruelty, ; , .
slain in an uprising of his people, II .

p: typical of Caesar.

p.#text: a deme of Attica on the bay of Phalerum, ; .

div2.head: Pythagoras

p.#text: of Samos (sixth century), studied in the Orient, great mathematician; moral and religious teacher; serious, ascetic, .
